captions.text: [Intro]

We here at SciShow want you to keep being
curious -- about the world, the universe,
even what’s going on in your own body.

And that is why we’ve teamed up with Google
and YouTube to answer ten of the most popular
science questions searched on the internet.

I'm Michael Aranda, and this is The World’s
Most Asked Questions.

Today’s question: How many calories should
I have in a day?

You’re probably asking because you want
to know how many is too many. After all, you

know that if you take in more energy than
you need, your body will store that excess
energy as fat.

But before we can talk about how many calories
you need, let’s start with what a calorie
is.

The calories that you find on food labels
aren’t the same as what scientists call
calories.

In chemistry, a calorie is the amount of energy
it takes to raise the temperature of one gram
of water by one degree Celsius.

But the calories listed on your can of soda
are actually kilocalories -- each one equal

to 1,000 of the “small calories” that
chemists use to measure energy.

So when your soda pop says it has 150 food
Calories -- you’ll notice it’s written

with a capital C -- that’s the same as 150,000
small calories -- with a little c.

So that’s enough energy to raise the temperature
of a whole liter of water by 150 degrees.
Kinda puts things in perspective.

But how many calories you need depends on
who you are, and how you live your life.
First, there’s your age to consider.

Despite the stereotype of the ravenous teenager,
your calorie demands actually peak when you’re
in your mid-20s.

That’s when your metabolism is higher than
at any other point in your life, and because

you keep growing into your 20s, once you're
done, you have more lean muscle mass which
requires more energy to maintain.

So, depending on your lifestyle and other
factors, when you’re in your 20s, you may
need from 2200 to 3000 calories a day!

Your sex is a factor, too. Men tend to have
more total body mass, and more muscle mass,

than women on average, so their caloric requirements
can be slightly higher.

According to the US Institute of Medicine,
the average calorie range for an adult woman

is 1800 to 2400 calories a day; for men, it
could be anywhere from 2000 to 3000.

But that’s obviously a pretty broad range.
And as delicious as it sounds, most of us

don’t need to be eating 3000 calories a
day.

And that’s because the most important factor,
by far, that affects your calorie needs is
your activity level.

For example, if you’re a woman in your 30s
or 40s, and you live a rather sedentary lifestyle

-- meaning you don’t set aside time for
any exercise -- then probably don't need any
more than 1800 calories on average.

But if you regularly take a nice brisk walk
-- say between 2.5 and 5 kilometers a day

-- then your caloric needs go up about 10%,
to 2000 calories.

And if you regularly walk more than 5 kilometers
-- or burn the equivalent amount of energy

doing some other exercise, like running -- then
you’re looking at another bump, up to 2,200
calories.

But when it comes to calorie intake, medical
professionals will tell you that the real

goal is to focus on your energy balance -- that’s
the balance of calories you take in compared

to the calories you burn through physical
activity.

So, naturally, if you burn more calories than
you take in, you’re going to have to use

more of the energy that you have stored up
as fat.

And, on the other hand, if you consume more
than you use, you’ll just keep building

up those “energy reserves” around your
midsection.

Since no one burns the same exact number of
calories that they eat every day, the key

is to maintain energy balance over the long
term.

So if you consistently ingest more energy
than you use, you’ll be out of balance -- just

as you would be if you keep burning more energy
than you supply for your body.
But, if you ask me? You look fantastic.

Now, SciShow survey funtime! Survey takers
who reported counting calories also reported

getting hiccups less than other survey takers.
Interesting, but it's important to note that
correlation does not equal causation.

Of all of the fascinating questions in the
world, what question do you want answered

most? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or
down in the comments below and we will answer

the best questions in a new video at the end
of the month. And don’t forget to use the

hashtag #WMAQ and stay tuned for other videos
this week.

title: World's Most Asked Questions: How Many Calories Should I Have in a Day?

comments.text:
Fat is mostly created when you consume to much sugar in a day. To high of a 
blood sugar can result in bad things, so the body creates a magical 
substance called insulin to save your life. It bonds to the sugar and 
creates body fat, which is then stored in your body. It then burns this 
over time at a more steady rate in order to keep the sugar from revealing 
its true nature as a dose based toxin.

Sadly, the food industry has packed their foods with sugar because sugar is 
addictive (x8 more than cocaine) and raises sales. in the 1980s, fats were 
replaced with sugar, and the obesity epidemic had been started up 
(ironically, the government had been trying to cut our waist sizes)

Its not calories in calories out, but what kind of calorie you are 
consuming.﻿

comments.text:
There is no "right" answer to every ones body. Every one is dif therefor 
every one needs dif calorie needs. You should not count calories, people in 
the old in days did not count calories, they ate when they were hungry and 
stopped when they were full. This kind of mentality is destructive and 
leads to eating disorders. The "2000" calorie study was reported on healthy 
people who were maintaining there weight and most of them reported on 
having 2000 calories but they were actually having 2500-3000 calories cause 
they forgot the hand full of nuts, tea, sugar, creamer, beer etc. if you 
have a healthy relationship with food than you will not obsessively count 
calories and measure, but listen to your body. I maintain a healthy weight 
after gaining weight from a eating disorder and I eat 2300-2900 calories 
every day and maintain! So I guess we will never know huh? And I'm very sad 
that this is the most asked question on Google ): ﻿

comments.text:
Actually, you burn calories regardless of excercise or strenuous activity. 
Everything that require work and energy requires calories. Whether it is 
running 10 laps around a football field or walking two feet to the door. 
Your body also needs energy. Let's not forgrt that movement happens inside 
your body such as the heart pumping blood and the lungs constantly 
contracting and expanding. Your body uses a certain part of all those 
calories (About 1,000 daily). The rest is burned off my movement. However, 
this does not mean that your body burns calories regardless of how much 
food you take. Excercise helps to speed up the process of calorie burning 
and in the long run, you get to eat more when you excercise. 
﻿

comments.author: PinkChucky15

comments.text:
Why aren't we attracted to fat people? It seems to me that evolution should 
have pushed us towards this, no? The more energy one has in reserve, the 
more they can sustain their life. Since food has been scarce for most of 
mankind's history, it would seem like this would be ideal. But no, we're 
programmed to seek out skinny people who have little in the way of energy 
stored.

Just seems strange to me. On that same note, those with genes that push 
them towards the skinny side are actually evolutionary oddities, since the 
goal is to have more energy. Skinny people burn more without cause, thereby 
being less efficient. We're hardwired to crave inefficiency.. ﻿
comments.author: UnknownXV

comments.text:
It has been scientifically proven that being fat is unhealthy, being 
unhealthy is bad for evolution. Evolution is keeping the good but getting 
rid of the bad, right? So if you are fat you are less likely to be as 
healthy and produce as many "good" offsprings as someone who is skinny. If 
the skinny persons offspring is healthier than the fat persons offspring, 
its offspring will win (survive better) in the long run, this is evolution, 
sort off. 

Evolution is partially survival of the fittest, fat people are more likely 
to suffer from disease and other health complications compared to skinny 
people. Thus skinny people would in the long run be better for your 
offspring than someone who is fat. It's in your best interest to spread 
your genes and create healthy offspring out of a evolutionary aspect.
By skinny I mean someone who has a healthy amount of fat, being too skinny 
just as, if not more unhealthy than being fat.

comments.text:
+DavorMATF "The thing is, we evolved as hunter-gatherers. No one ever got 
unhealthy fat before processed food."
+Jacob Lee "Yeah they did. Henry the 8th was obese by todays standards."

WHOAH NOW! Let's distinguish between hunter-gatherer times and recent 
history please! People have been stunted and prone to both diseases of 
malnutrition and diseases of affluence since the agricultural revolution. 
Hippocrates recognized obesity as a malady to be avoided, and study of 
early mummies revealed signs of heart disease across the board.
edit: It's just much worse now due to huge consumption of sugar, wheat, and 
seed oils.

century having a little extra weight (not obese) was seen as attractive and

little extra weight to support a pregnancy was seen positive.  This can 
been viewed as evolutionary, wanting to be with the best possible woman to

you are fat you obviously have money, fit but heavy set means you work for

Doesn't help when the quacks who ran the study are talking out their asses 
too.

>>>2.) No one said anything about changing anything. These studies are to 
help understand the psychology of preferences.<<<

Bullshit. They don't help us understand anything. You know why? Because 
they started with the conclusion bases on their ideology and then ran an 
"experiment" to confirm the conclusion that they had already come to.

>>>3.) Don't want to read them all? That's what abstracts are for.<<<

How about you just sum it up. I've already wasted enough time on you.

>>>4.) I've said this to someone else before: Standards of beauty =/= 
sexual orientation.<<<

So attraction is biologically hardwired when it suits your ideology and 
just a cultural construct when it doesn't.

Here is a gorgeous girl for you:
http://images.sodahead.com/polls/000314787/polls_UglyGirl_2447_390813_poll_xlarge.jpeg

Don't let society tell you what is beautiful. You know she is hot.

Here is another one:

http://c3e308.medialib.glogster.com/media/07/070c8f68911587564643a72fb6ebeb5f754d4e39f22c27668d4919c6dc7a9be6/scarygirl.jpg

If you are normal you probably got a feeling of disgust or fear from the 
last one. Kinda like it's biologically hardwired right? Weird.

>>>5.) Since when is showing actual academic research from respected 
professors anti-science?<<<

1.When you start with the conclusion.

2.When your "respected professors" are nothing but charlatans.

>>>I thought that was the definition of providing evidence.<<<

Why is it so hard to find studies showing the opposite. That in fact 
attraction is almost entirely hardwired. Oh right, because it's fucking 
obvious. Would you fund a study into whether or not people that go into 
water get wet?

The only people that conduct and fund studies like that are people with an 
agenda.

>>>Oh right, you weren't looking for evidence:<<<

Are you looking for evidence that the sky looks blue?

>>>I could tell from your username that your response would be much more 
ideologically driven than mine and I wasn't wrong.<<<

I think of my username as an idiot detector. If you don't get it then you 
are almost definitely a moron. Congrats, you failed the test. Hint: I'ts 
satirical you idiot.

>>>I honestly don't care what else you have to say.<<<

Of course you don'. It doesn't fit with your narrative.

Back to your echo chamber fool.

>>>I just a saw a good excuse to link to some interesting studies for 
people who aren't pseudo-intellectuals as I have, thankfully, exposed you 
to be.<<<

^This is what psychological projection looks like.

Have a nice day!

comments.author: evilmick66

comments.text:
Great question. First of all, don't listen to +evilmick66 , he is talking 
out his ass.

Think about it this way, obesity is a pretty new phenomenon. In the wild it 
would have been extremely rare. Just as you never see fat lions or a fat 
gazelle so there were hardly any fat humans. Yes we evolved to store fat 
when food is abundant but that amount of fat would have been too little to 
to drastically change the shape of a persons figure, and in times of 
scarcity those reserves would be burned away.

Being obese distorts a persons body shape to the point where our animal 
mind no longer recognizes the person an an object of desire. We find a 
slender figure sexy because that is what we evolved to see as sexy.

We evolved to be attracted to this:
http://image.shutterstock.com/display_pic_with_logo/537295/126099392/stock-vector-silhouettes-of-beautiful-girls-vector-126099392.jpg

and not this:
http://3.bp.blogspot.com/_REkgXByDyuU/TKXIfSmqPqI/AAAAAAAAJpA/8-HE_8aCVDs/s1600/Fat_Mudflap_Girl.jpg
comments.author: If you are not a White-ist, you are a bigot.

comments.text:
In response to the original poster. Being fat would not be an evolutionary 
advantage in the pre-agricultural world. Being fit, strong, agile, and 
sociable would have been the best predictors of evolutionary 
advantage/ability to mate/long life. Until 10,000 years ago "access to 
food" was not something accrued by individuals, but by the tribe on a day 
to day basis as a function of how plentiful the surrounding region was in 
that particular season.

ballpark.
